cells.data:
Nested Quantifiers

$\forall x : \exists y : x + y = 1$
vs
$\exists y : \forall x : x + y = 1$

Order matters when the quantifiers differ

Rules of Inference

Premises
$p \implies q$, given $p$, we can assert $q$ to be true
However, $p \implies q$, given $\neg p$, we can assert nothing about $q$
Similary, we cannot conclude $p$ from $q$

An argument must start with some premises and end with a conclusion
It is valid when the premises logically imply the conclusion (alternatively, when the conclusion follows from the premises)
A proof is a valid argument that establishes the truth value of a statement

An argument is then a sequence of propositions. All but the final are called premises. The final one is the conclusion
Valid if truth of premises implies truth of conclusions

$(p_1 \land \dots \land p_n) \implies q$ is a tautology

E.g.,
$p \implies q$
$p$
$\therefore q$

Is $((p \implies q) \land p) \implies q$ a tautology?
Truth tables...

Contrast with
$p \implies q$
$q$
$\therefore p$

Is $((p \implies q) \land q) \implies p$ a tautology?

Known valid arg forms:

Modus ponens: $((p \implies q) \land p) \implies q$
Modus tollens: $((p \implies q) \land \neg q) \implies \neg p$
$(p \implies q) \land (q \implies r) \implies (p \implies r)$
$((p \lor q) \land \neg p) \implies q$
Addition: $p \implies (p \lor q)$
Simplification: $(p \land q) \implies p$
$(p) \land (q) \implies (p \land q)$
$(p \lor q) \land (\neg p \lor r) \implies (q \lor r)$
